trans-unit.source: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: Use Hadoop clusters | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action: Use Hadoop clusters | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) for an end-to-end scenario employing an HDInsight Hadoop cluster to build and deploy a model using a publicly available dataset.
trans-unit.target: Using the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) for an end-to-end scenario employing an HDInsight Hadoop cluster to build and deploy a model using a publicly available dataset.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, you use the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) in an end-to-end scenario using an <linkText>Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster</linkText><title></title> to store, explore and feature engineer data from the publicly available <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset, and to down sample the data.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, you use the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology (ADAPT) in an end-to-end scenario using an <linkText>Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster</linkText><title></title> to store, explore and feature engineer data from the publicly available <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset, and to down sample the data.

trans-unit.source: Models of the data are built with Azure Machine Learning to handle binary and multiclass classification and regression predictive tasks.
trans-unit.target: Models of the data are built with Azure Machine Learning to handle binary and multiclass classification and regression predictive tasks.

trans-unit.source: For a walkthrough that shows how to handle a larger (1 terabyte) dataset for a similar scenario using HDInsight Hadoop clusters for data processing, see <linkText>Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action - Using Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters on a 1 TB dataset</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For a walkthrough that shows how to handle a larger (1 terabyte) dataset for a similar scenario using HDInsight Hadoop clusters for data processing, see <linkText>Advanced Analytics Process and Technology in Action - Using Azure HDInsight Hadoop Clusters on a 1 TB dataset</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It is also possible to use an IPython notebook to accomplish the tasks presented the walkthrough using the 1 TB dataset.
trans-unit.target: It is also possible to use an IPython notebook to accomplish the tasks presented the walkthrough using the 1 TB dataset.

trans-unit.source: Users who would like to try this approach should consult the <linkText>Criteo walkthrough using a Hive ODBC connection</linkText><title></title> topic.
trans-unit.target: Users who would like to try this approach should consult the <linkText>Criteo walkthrough using a Hive ODBC connection</linkText><title></title> topic.

trans-unit.source: The NYC Taxi Trip data is about 20GB of compressed comma-separated values (CSV) files (~48GB uncompressed), comprising more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.
trans-unit.target: The NYC Taxi Trip data is about 20GB of compressed comma-separated values (CSV) files (~48GB uncompressed), comprising more than 173 million individual trips and the fares paid for each trip.

trans-unit.source: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off location and time, anonymized hack (driver's) license number and medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.
trans-unit.target: Each trip record includes the pickup and drop-off location and time, anonymized hack (driver's) license number and medallion (taxi’s unique id) number.

trans-unit.source: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:
trans-unit.target: The data covers all trips in the year 2013 and is provided in the following two datasets for each month:

trans-unit.source: The 'trip_data' CSV files contain trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.
trans-unit.target: The 'trip_data' CSV files contain trip details, such as number of passengers, pickup and dropoff points, trip duration, and trip length.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The 'trip_fare' CSV files contain details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.
trans-unit.target: The 'trip_fare' CSV files contain details of the fare paid for each trip, such as payment type, fare amount, surcharge and taxes, tips and tolls, and the total amount paid.

trans-unit.source: Here are a few sample records:
trans-unit.target: Here are a few sample records:

trans-unit.source: The unique key to join trip\data and trip\fare is composed of the fields: medallion, hack\licence and pickup\datetime.
trans-unit.target: The unique key to join trip\data and trip\fare is composed of the fields: medallion, hack\licence and pickup\datetime.

trans-unit.source: To get all of the details relevant to a particular trip, it is sufficient to join with three keys: the "medallion", "hack\license" and "pickup\datetime".
trans-unit.target: To get all of the details relevant to a particular trip, it is sufficient to join with three keys: the "medallion", "hack\license" and "pickup\datetime".

trans-unit.source: We describe some more details of the data when we store them into Hive tables shortly.
trans-unit.target: We describe some more details of the data when we store them into Hive tables shortly.

trans-unit.source: When approaching data, determining the kind of predictions you want to make based on its analysis helps clarify the tasks that you will need to include in your process.
trans-unit.target: When approaching data, determining the kind of predictions you want to make based on its analysis helps clarify the tasks that you will need to include in your process.

trans-unit.source: Here are three examples of prediction problems that we address in this walkthrough whose formulation is based on the tip\_amount:
trans-unit.target: Here are three examples of prediction problems that we address in this walkthrough whose formulation is based on the tip\_amount:

trans-unit.source: Binary classification: Predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a tip\_amount that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a tip\_amount of $0 is a negative example.
trans-unit.target: Binary classification: Predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip, i.e. a tip\_amount that is greater than $0 is a positive example, while a tip\_amount of $0 is a negative example.

trans-unit.source: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip amounts paid for the trip.
trans-unit.target: Multiclass classification: To predict the range of tip amounts paid for the trip.

trans-unit.source: We divide the tip\_amount into five bins or classes:
trans-unit.target: We divide the tip\_amount into five bins or classes:

trans-unit.source: Regression task: To predict the amount of the tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Regression task: To predict the amount of the tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: You can set up an Azure environment for advanced analytics that employs an HDInsight cluster in three steps:
trans-unit.target: You can set up an Azure environment for advanced analytics that employs an HDInsight cluster in three steps:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>: This storage account is used for storing data in Azure Blob Storage.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create a storage account</linkText><title></title>: This storage account is used for storing data in Azure Blob Storage.

trans-unit.source: The data used in HDInsight clusters also resides here.
trans-unit.target: The data used in HDInsight clusters also resides here.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Customize Azure HDInsight Hadoop clusters for the Advanced Analytics Process and Technology</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This step creates an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster with 64-bit Anaconda Python 2.7 installed on all nodes.
trans-unit.target: This step creates an Azure HDInsight Hadoop cluster with 64-bit Anaconda Python 2.7 installed on all nodes.

trans-unit.source: There are two important steps to remember while customizing your HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: There are two important steps to remember while customizing your HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: Remember to link the storage account created in step 1 with your HDInsight cluster when creating it.
trans-unit.target: Remember to link the storage account created in step 1 with your HDInsight cluster when creating it.

trans-unit.source: This storage account is used to access data that is processed within the cluster.
trans-unit.target: This storage account is used to access data that is processed within the cluster.

trans-unit.source: After the cluster is created, enable Remote Access to the head node of the cluster.
trans-unit.target: After the cluster is created, enable Remote Access to the head node of the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Navigate to the Configuration tab and click Enable Remote.
trans-unit.target: Navigate to the Configuration tab and click Enable Remote.

trans-unit.source: This step specifies the user credentials used for remote login.
trans-unit.target: This step specifies the user credentials used for remote login.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace</linkText><title></title>: This Azure Machine Learning workspace is used to build machine learning models.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Create an Azure Machine Learning workspace</linkText><title></title>: This Azure Machine Learning workspace is used to build machine learning models.

trans-unit.source: This task is addressed after completing an initial data exploration and down sampling using the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: This task is addressed after completing an initial data exploration and down sampling using the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: To get the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset from its public location, you may use any of the methods described in <linkText>Move Data to and from Azure Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to copy the data to your machine.
trans-unit.target: To get the <linkText>NYC Taxi Trips</linkText><title></title> dataset from its public location, you may use any of the methods described in <linkText>Move Data to and from Azure Blob Storage</linkText><title></title> to copy the data to your machine.

trans-unit.source: Here we describe how use AzCopy to transfer the files containing data.
trans-unit.target: Here we describe how use AzCopy to transfer the files containing data.

trans-unit.source: To download and install AzCopy follow the instructions at <linkText>Getting Started with the AzCopy Command-Line Utility</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To download and install AzCopy follow the instructions at <linkText>Getting Started with the AzCopy Command-Line Utility</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: From a Command Prompt window, issue the following AzCopy commands, replacing with the desired destination:
trans-unit.target: From a Command Prompt window, issue the following AzCopy commands, replacing with the desired destination:

trans-unit.source: When the copy completes, a total of 24 zipped files are in the data folder chosen. Unzip the downloaded files to the same directory on your local machine. Make a note of the folder where the uncompressed files reside. This folder will be referred to as the is what follows.
trans-unit.target: When the copy completes, a total of 24 zipped files are in the data folder chosen. Unzip the downloaded files to the same directory on your local machine. Make a note of the folder where the uncompressed files reside. This folder will be referred to as the is what follows.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: In the following AzCopy commands, replace the following parameters with the actual values that you specified when creating the Hadoop cluster and unzipping the data files.
trans-unit.target: In the following AzCopy commands, replace the following parameters with the actual values that you specified when creating the Hadoop cluster and unzipping the data files.

trans-unit.source: *<path_to_data_folder>* the directory (along with path) on your machine that contain the unzipped data files
trans-unit.target: *<path_to_data_folder>* the directory (along with path) on your machine that contain the unzipped data files

trans-unit.source: *<storage account name of Hadoop cluster>* the storage account associated with your HDInsight cluster
trans-unit.target: *<storage account name of Hadoop cluster>* the storage account associated with your HDInsight cluster

trans-unit.source: *<default container of Hadoop cluster>* the default container used by your cluster.
trans-unit.target: *<default container of Hadoop cluster>* the default container used by your cluster.

trans-unit.source: Note that the name of the default container is usually the same name as the cluster itself.
trans-unit.target: Note that the name of the default container is usually the same name as the cluster itself.

trans-unit.source: For example, if the cluster is called "abc123.azurehdinsight.net", the default container is abc123.
trans-unit.target: For example, if the cluster is called "abc123.azurehdinsight.net", the default container is abc123.

trans-unit.source: *<storage account key>* the key for the storage account used by your cluster
trans-unit.target: *<storage account key>* the key for the storage account used by your cluster

trans-unit.source: From a Command Prompt or a Windows PowerShell window in your machine, run the following two AzCopy commands.
trans-unit.target: From a Command Prompt or a Windows PowerShell window in your machine, run the following two AzCopy commands.

trans-unit.source: This command uploads the trip data to *nyctaxitripraw* directory in the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: This command uploads the trip data to *nyctaxitripraw* directory in the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: This command uploads the fare data to *nyctaxifareraw* directory in the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: This command uploads the fare data to *nyctaxifareraw* directory in the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: The data should now in Azure Blob Storage and ready to be consumed within the HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: The data should now in Azure Blob Storage and ready to be consumed within the HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: To access the head node of the cluster for exploratory data analysis and down sampling of the data, follow the procedure outlined in <linkText>Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To access the head node of the cluster for exploratory data analysis and down sampling of the data, follow the procedure outlined in <linkText>Access the Head Node of Hadoop Cluster</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In this walkthrough, we primarily use queries written in <linkText>Hive</linkText><title></title>, a SQL-like query language, to perform preliminary data explorations.
trans-unit.target: In this walkthrough, we primarily use queries written in <linkText>Hive</linkText><title></title>, a SQL-like query language, to perform preliminary data explorations.

trans-unit.source: The Hive queries are stored in .hql files.
trans-unit.target: The Hive queries are stored in .hql files.

trans-unit.source: We then down sample this data to be used within Azure Machine Learning for building models.
trans-unit.target: We then down sample this data to be used within Azure Machine Learning for building models.

trans-unit.source: To prepare the cluster for exploratory data analysis, we download the .hql files containing the relevant Hive scripts from <linkText>github</linkText><title></title> to a local directory (C:\temp) on the head node.
trans-unit.target: To prepare the cluster for exploratory data analysis, we download the .hql files containing the relevant Hive scripts from <linkText>github</linkText><title></title> to a local directory (C:\temp) on the head node.

trans-unit.source: To do this, open the Command Prompt from within the head node of the cluster and issue the following two commands:
trans-unit.target: To do this, open the Command Prompt from within the head node of the cluster and issue the following two commands:

trans-unit.source: These two commands will download all .hql files needed in this walkthrough to the local directory *C:\temp\* in the head node.
trans-unit.target: These two commands will download all .hql files needed in this walkthrough to the local directory *C:\temp\* in the head node.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: We are now ready to create Hive tables for our NYC taxi dataset.
trans-unit.target: We are now ready to create Hive tables for our NYC taxi dataset.

trans-unit.source: In the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the *Hadoop Command Line* on the desktop of the head node, and enter the Hive directory by entering the command
trans-unit.target: In the head node of the Hadoop cluster, open the *Hadoop Command Line* on the desktop of the head node, and enter the Hive directory by entering the command

trans-unit.source: **Run all Hive commands in this walkthrough from the above Hive bin/ directory prompt.
trans-unit.target: **Run all Hive commands in this walkthrough from the above Hive bin/ directory prompt.

trans-unit.source: This will take care of any path issues automatically.
trans-unit.target: This will take care of any path issues automatically.

trans-unit.source: We use the terms "Hive directory prompt", "Hive bin/ directory prompt", and "Hadoop Command Line" interchangeably in this walkthrough.**
trans-unit.target: We use the terms "Hive directory prompt", "Hive bin/ directory prompt", and "Hadoop Command Line" interchangeably in this walkthrough.**

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, enter the following command in Hadoop Command Line of the head node to submit the Hive query to create Hive database and tables:
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, enter the following command in Hadoop Command Line of the head node to submit the Hive query to create Hive database and tables:

trans-unit.source: Here is the content of the *C:\temp\sample\_hive\_create\_db\_and\_tables.hql* file which creates Hive database *nyctaxidb* and tables *trip* and *fare*.
trans-unit.target: Here is the content of the *C:\temp\sample\_hive\_create\_db\_and\_tables.hql* file which creates Hive database *nyctaxidb* and tables *trip* and *fare*.

trans-unit.source: This Hive script creates two tables:
trans-unit.target: This Hive script creates two tables:

trans-unit.source: the "trip" table contains trip details of each ride (driver details, pickup time, trip distance and times)
trans-unit.target: the "trip" table contains trip details of each ride (driver details, pickup time, trip distance and times)

trans-unit.source: the "fare" table contains fare details (fare amount, tip amount, tolls and surcharges).
trans-unit.target: the "fare" table contains fare details (fare amount, tip amount, tolls and surcharges).

trans-unit.source: If you need any additional assistance with these procedures or want to investigate alternative ones, see the section <linkText>Submit Hive queries directly from the Hadoop Command Line </linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need any additional assistance with these procedures or want to investigate alternative ones, see the section <linkText>Submit Hive queries directly from the Hadoop Command Line </linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This is typically an Admin task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically an Admin task.

trans-unit.source: The NYC taxi dataset has a natural partitioning by month, which we use to enable faster processing and query times.
trans-unit.target: The NYC taxi dataset has a natural partitioning by month, which we use to enable faster processing and query times.

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell commands below (issued from the Hive directory using the Hadoop Command Line) load data to the "trip" and "fare" Hive tables partitioned by month.
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell commands below (issued from the Hive directory using the Hadoop Command Line) load data to the "trip" and "fare" Hive tables partitioned by month.

trans-unit.source: The sample\_hive\_load\_data\_by\_partitions.hql file contains the following LOAD commands.
trans-unit.target: The sample\_hive\_load\_data\_by\_partitions.hql file contains the following LOAD commands.

trans-unit.source: Note that a number of Hive queries we use here in the exploration process involve looking at just a single partition or at only a couple of partitions.
trans-unit.target: Note that a number of Hive queries we use here in the exploration process involve looking at just a single partition or at only a couple of partitions.

trans-unit.source: But these queries could be run across the entire data.
trans-unit.target: But these queries could be run across the entire data.

trans-unit.source: The data exploration and feature engineering tasks for the data loaded into the Hive tables can be accomplished using Hive queries.
trans-unit.target: The data exploration and feature engineering tasks for the data loaded into the Hive tables can be accomplished using Hive queries.

trans-unit.source: Here are examples of such tasks that we walk you through in this section:
trans-unit.target: Here are examples of such tasks that we walk you through in this section:

trans-unit.source: View the top 10 records in both tables.
trans-unit.target: View the top 10 records in both tables.

trans-unit.source: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.
trans-unit.target: Explore data distributions of a few fields in varying time windows.

trans-unit.source: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.
trans-unit.target: Investigate data quality of the longitude and latitude fields.

trans-unit.source: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the tip\_amount.
trans-unit.target: Generate binary and multiclass classification labels based on the tip\_amount.

trans-unit.source: Generate features by computing the direct trip distances.
trans-unit.target: Generate features by computing the direct trip distances.

trans-unit.source: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.target: To see what the data looks like, we examine 10 records from each table.

trans-unit.source: Of interest is the how the number of trips varies during the calendar year.
trans-unit.target: Of interest is the how the number of trips varies during the calendar year.

trans-unit.target: This gives us the output :

trans-unit.target: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: This example identifies the medallion (taxi numbers) with more than 100 trips within a given time period.
trans-unit.target: This example identifies the medallion (taxi numbers) with more than 100 trips within a given time period.

trans-unit.source: The query benefits from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition variable month.
trans-unit.target: The query benefits from the partitioned table access since it is conditioned by the partition variable month.

trans-unit.source: The query results are written to a local file queryoutput.tsv in C:\temp on the head node.
trans-unit.target: The query results are written to a local file queryoutput.tsv in C:\temp on the head node.

trans-unit.source: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion.hql file for inspection.
trans-unit.target: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion.hql file for inspection.

trans-unit.source: The medallion in the NYC taxi data set identifies a unique cab.
trans-unit.target: The medallion in the NYC taxi data set identifies a unique cab.

trans-unit.source: We can identify which cabs are "busy" by asking which ones made more than a certain number of trips in a particular time period.
trans-unit.target: We can identify which cabs are "busy" by asking which ones made more than a certain number of trips in a particular time period.

trans-unit.source: The following example identifies cabs that made more than a hundred trips in the first three months, and saves the query results to a local file, C:\temp\queryoutput.tsv.
trans-unit.target: The following example identifies cabs that made more than a hundred trips in the first three months, and saves the query results to a local file, C:\temp\queryoutput.tsv.

trans-unit.source: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion.hql file for inspection.
trans-unit.target: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion.hql file for inspection.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, issue the command below :
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, issue the command below :

trans-unit.source: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: When exploring a dataset, we frequently want to examine the number of co-occurences of groups of values.
trans-unit.target: When exploring a dataset, we frequently want to examine the number of co-occurences of groups of values.

trans-unit.source: This section provide an example of how to do this for cabs and drivers.
trans-unit.target: This section provide an example of how to do this for cabs and drivers.

trans-unit.source: The sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion\_license.hql file groups the fare data set on "medallion" and "hack_license" and returns counts of each combination.
trans-unit.target: The sample\_hive\_trip\_count\_by\_medallion\_license.hql file groups the fare data set on "medallion" and "hack_license" and returns counts of each combination.

trans-unit.source: Below are its contents.
trans-unit.target: Below are its contents.

trans-unit.source: This query returns cab and particular driver combinations ordered by descending number of trips.
trans-unit.target: This query returns cab and particular driver combinations ordered by descending number of trips.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, run :
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, run :

trans-unit.source: The query results are written to a local file C:\temp\queryoutput.tsv.
trans-unit.target: The query results are written to a local file C:\temp\queryoutput.tsv.

trans-unit.source: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: A common objective of exploratory data analysis is to weed out invalid or bad records.
trans-unit.target: A common objective of exploratory data analysis is to weed out invalid or bad records.

trans-unit.source: The example in this section determines whether either the longitude or latitude fields contain a value far outside the NYC area.
trans-unit.target: The example in this section determines whether either the longitude or latitude fields contain a value far outside the NYC area.

trans-unit.source: Since it is likely that such records have an erroneous longitude-latitude values, we want to eliminate them from any data that is to be used for modeling.
trans-unit.target: Since it is likely that such records have an erroneous longitude-latitude values, we want to eliminate them from any data that is to be used for modeling.

trans-unit.source: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_quality\_assessment.hql file for inspection.
trans-unit.target: Here is the content of sample\_hive\_quality\_assessment.hql file for inspection.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, run :
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, run :

trans-unit.source: The -S argument included in this command suppresses the status screen printout of the Hive Map/Reduce jobs.
trans-unit.target: The -S argument included in this command suppresses the status screen printout of the Hive Map/Reduce jobs.

trans-unit.source: This is useful because it makes the screen print of the Hive query output more readable.
trans-unit.target: This is useful because it makes the screen print of the Hive query output more readable.

trans-unit.source: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: For the binary classification problem outlined in the <linkText>Examples of prediction tasks</linkText><title></title> section, it is useful to know whether a tip was given or not.
trans-unit.target: For the binary classification problem outlined in the <linkText>Examples of prediction tasks</linkText><title></title> section, it is useful to know whether a tip was given or not.

trans-unit.source: This distribution of tips is binary:
trans-unit.target: This distribution of tips is binary:

trans-unit.source: tip given(Class 1, tip\_amount > $0)
trans-unit.target: tip given(Class 1, tip\_amount > $0)

trans-unit.source: no tip (Class 0, tip\_amount = $0).
trans-unit.target: no tip (Class 0, tip\_amount = $0).

trans-unit.source: The sample\_hive\_tipped\_frequencies.hql file shown below does this.
trans-unit.target: The sample\_hive\_tipped\_frequencies.hql file shown below does this.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, run:
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, run:

trans-unit.source: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: For the multiclass classification problem outlined in the <linkText>Examples of prediction tasks</linkText><title></title> section this data set also lends itself to a natural classification where we would like to predict the amount of the tips given.
trans-unit.target: For the multiclass classification problem outlined in the <linkText>Examples of prediction tasks</linkText><title></title> section this data set also lends itself to a natural classification where we would like to predict the amount of the tips given.

trans-unit.source: We can use bins to define tip ranges in the query.
trans-unit.target: We can use bins to define tip ranges in the query.

trans-unit.source: To get the class distributions for the various tip ranges, we use the sample\_hive\_tip\_range\_frequencies.hql file.
trans-unit.target: To get the class distributions for the various tip ranges, we use the sample\_hive\_tip\_range\_frequencies.hql file.

trans-unit.source: Below are its contents.
trans-unit.target: Below are its contents.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command from Hadoop Command Line console:
trans-unit.target: Run the following command from Hadoop Command Line console:

trans-unit.source: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: Having a measure of the direct distance allows us to find out the discrepancy between it and the actual trip distance.
trans-unit.target: Having a measure of the direct distance allows us to find out the discrepancy between it and the actual trip distance.

trans-unit.source: We motivate this feature by pointing out that a passenger might be less likely to tip if they figure out that the driver has intentionally taken them by a much longer route.
trans-unit.target: We motivate this feature by pointing out that a passenger might be less likely to tip if they figure out that the driver has intentionally taken them by a much longer route.

trans-unit.source: To see the comparison between actual trip distance and the <linkText>Haversine distance</linkText><title></title> between two longitude-latitude points (the "great circle" distance), we use the trigonometric functions available within Hive, thus :
trans-unit.target: To see the comparison between actual trip distance and the <linkText>Haversine distance</linkText><title></title> between two longitude-latitude points (the "great circle" distance), we use the trigonometric functions available within Hive, thus :

trans-unit.source: In the query above, R is the radius of the Earth in miles, and pi is converted to radians.
trans-unit.target: In the query above, R is the radius of the Earth in miles, and pi is converted to radians.

trans-unit.source: Note that the longitude-latitude points are "filtered" to remove values that are far from the NYC area.
trans-unit.target: Note that the longitude-latitude points are "filtered" to remove values that are far from the NYC area.

trans-unit.source: In this case, we write our results to a directory called "queryoutputdir".
trans-unit.target: In this case, we write our results to a directory called "queryoutputdir".

trans-unit.source: The sequence of commands shown below first creates this output directory, and then runs the Hive command.
trans-unit.target: The sequence of commands shown below first creates this output directory, and then runs the Hive command.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, run:
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, run:

trans-unit.source: The query results are written to 9 Azure blobs *queryoutputdir/000000\_0* to *queryoutputdir/000008\_0* under the default container of the Hadoop cluster.
trans-unit.target: The query results are written to 9 Azure blobs *queryoutputdir/000000\_0* to *queryoutputdir/000008\_0* under the default container of the Hadoop cluster.

trans-unit.source: To see the size of the individual blobs, we run the following command from the Hive directory prompt :
trans-unit.target: To see the size of the individual blobs, we run the following command from the Hive directory prompt :

trans-unit.source: To see the contents of a given file, say 000000\_0, we use Hadoop's copyToLocal command, thus.
trans-unit.target: To see the contents of a given file, say 000000\_0, we use Hadoop's copyToLocal command, thus.

trans-unit.source: Warning: copyToLocal can be very slow for large files, and is not recommended for use with them.
trans-unit.target: Warning: copyToLocal can be very slow for large files, and is not recommended for use with them.

trans-unit.source: A key advantage of having this data reside in an Azure blob is that we may explore the data within Azure Machine Learning using the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: A key advantage of having this data reside in an Azure blob is that we may explore the data within Azure Machine Learning using the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.
trans-unit.target: Note: This is typically a Data Scientist task.

trans-unit.source: After the exploratory data analysis phase, we are now ready to down sample the data for building models in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: After the exploratory data analysis phase, we are now ready to down sample the data for building models in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: In this section, we show how to use a Hive query to down sample the data, which is then accessed from the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: In this section, we show how to use a Hive query to down sample the data, which is then accessed from the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: There are two steps in this procedure.
trans-unit.target: There are two steps in this procedure.

trans-unit.source: First we join the nyctaxidb.trip and nyctaxidb.fare tables on three keys that are present in all records : "medallion", "hack\license", and "pickup\datetime".
trans-unit.target: First we join the nyctaxidb.trip and nyctaxidb.fare tables on three keys that are present in all records : "medallion", "hack\license", and "pickup\datetime".

trans-unit.source: We then generate a binary classification label tipped and a multi-class classification label tip\_class.
trans-unit.target: We then generate a binary classification label tipped and a multi-class classification label tip\_class.

trans-unit.source: To be able to use the down sampled data directly from the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning, it is necessary to store the results of the above query to an internal Hive table.
trans-unit.target: To be able to use the down sampled data directly from the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module in Azure Machine Learning, it is necessary to store the results of the above query to an internal Hive table.

trans-unit.source: In what follows, we create an internal Hive table and populate its contents with the joined and down sampled data.
trans-unit.target: In what follows, we create an internal Hive table and populate its contents with the joined and down sampled data.

trans-unit.source: The query applies standard Hive functions directly to generate the hour of day, week of year, weekday (1 stands for Monday, and 7 stands for Sunday) from the "pickup\_datetime" field, and the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff locations.
trans-unit.target: The query applies standard Hive functions directly to generate the hour of day, week of year, weekday (1 stands for Monday, and 7 stands for Sunday) from the "pickup\_datetime" field, and the direct distance between the pickup and dropoff locations.

trans-unit.source: Users can refer to <linkText>LanguageManual UDF</linkText><title></title> for a complete list of such functions.
trans-unit.target: Users can refer to <linkText>LanguageManual UDF</linkText><title></title> for a complete list of such functions.

trans-unit.source: The query then down samples the data so that the query results can fit into the Azure Machine Learning Studio.
trans-unit.target: The query then down samples the data so that the query results can fit into the Azure Machine Learning Studio.

trans-unit.source: Only about 1% of the original dataset is imported into the Studio.
trans-unit.target: Only about 1% of the original dataset is imported into the Studio.

trans-unit.source: Below are the contents of sample\_hive\_prepare\_for\_aml\_full.hql file that prepares data for model building in Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: Below are the contents of sample\_hive\_prepare\_for\_aml\_full.hql file that prepares data for model building in Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: To run this query, from the Hive directory prompt :
trans-unit.target: To run this query, from the Hive directory prompt :

trans-unit.source: We now have an internal table "nyctaxidb.nyctaxidownsampleddataset" which can be accessed using the Reader[reader] module from Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: We now have an internal table "nyctaxidb.nyctaxidownsampleddataset" which can be accessed using the Reader[reader] module from Azure Machine Learning.

trans-unit.source: Furthermore, we may use this dataset for building Machine Learning models.
trans-unit.target: Furthermore, we may use this dataset for building Machine Learning models.

trans-unit.source: As prerequisites for issuing Hive queries in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module of Azure Machine Learning, we need access to an Azure Machine Learning workspace and access to the credentials of the cluster and its associated storage account.
trans-unit.target: As prerequisites for issuing Hive queries in the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module of Azure Machine Learning, we need access to an Azure Machine Learning workspace and access to the credentials of the cluster and its associated storage account.

trans-unit.source: Some details on the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module and the parameters to input :
trans-unit.target: Some details on the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module and the parameters to input :

trans-unit.source: HCatalog server URI: If the cluster name is abc123, then this is simply : https://abc123.azurehdinsight.net
trans-unit.target: HCatalog server URI: If the cluster name is abc123, then this is simply : https://abc123.azurehdinsight.net

trans-unit.source: Hadoop user account name : The user name chosen for the cluster (not the remote access user name)
trans-unit.target: Hadoop user account name : The user name chosen for the cluster (not the remote access user name)

trans-unit.source: Hadoop ser account password : The password chosen for the cluster (not the remote access password)
trans-unit.target: Hadoop ser account password : The password chosen for the cluster (not the remote access password)

trans-unit.source: Location of output data : This is chosen to be Azure.
trans-unit.target: Location of output data : This is chosen to be Azure.

trans-unit.source: Azure storage account name : Name of the default storage account associated with the cluster.
trans-unit.target: Azure storage account name : Name of the default storage account associated with the cluster.

trans-unit.source: Azure container name : This is the default container name for the cluster, and is typically the same as the cluster name.
trans-unit.target: Azure container name : This is the default container name for the cluster, and is typically the same as the cluster name.

trans-unit.source: For a cluster called "abc123", this is just abc123.
trans-unit.target: For a cluster called "abc123", this is just abc123.

trans-unit.source: Important Note: **Any table we wish to query using the Reader[reader] module in Azure Machine Learning must be an internal table.** A tip for determining if a table T in a database D.db is an internal table is as follows.
trans-unit.target: Important Note: **Any table we wish to query using the Reader[reader] module in Azure Machine Learning must be an internal table.** A tip for determining if a table T in a database D.db is an internal table is as follows.

trans-unit.source: From the Hive directory prompt, issue the command :
trans-unit.target: From the Hive directory prompt, issue the command :

trans-unit.source: If the table is an internal table and it is populated, its contents must show here.
trans-unit.target: If the table is an internal table and it is populated, its contents must show here.

trans-unit.source: Another way to determine whether a table is an internal table is to use the Azure Storage Explorer.
trans-unit.target: Another way to determine whether a table is an internal table is to use the Azure Storage Explorer.

trans-unit.source: Use it to navigate to the default container name of the cluster, and then filter by the table name.
trans-unit.target: Use it to navigate to the default container name of the cluster, and then filter by the table name.

trans-unit.source: If the table and its contents show up, this confirms that it is an internal table.
trans-unit.target: If the table and its contents show up, this confirms that it is an internal table.

trans-unit.source: Here is a snapshot of the Hive query and the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module:
trans-unit.target: Here is a snapshot of the Hive query and the <linkText>Reader[reader]</linkText><title></title> module:

trans-unit.source: Note that since our down sampled data resides in the default container, the resulting Hive query from Azure Machine Learning is very simple and is just a "SELECT * FROM nyctaxidb.nyctaxi\downsampled\data".
trans-unit.target: Note that since our down sampled data resides in the default container, the resulting Hive query from Azure Machine Learning is very simple and is just a "SELECT * FROM nyctaxidb.nyctaxi\downsampled\data".

trans-unit.source: The dataset may now be used as the starting point for building Machine Learning models.
trans-unit.target: The dataset may now be used as the starting point for building Machine Learning models.

trans-unit.source: We are now able to proceed to model building and model deployment in <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: We are now able to proceed to model building and model deployment in <linkText>Azure Machine Learning</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The data is ready for us to use in addressing the prediction problems identified above:
trans-unit.target: The data is ready for us to use in addressing the prediction problems identified above:

trans-unit.source: Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Binary classification**: To predict whether or not a tip was paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: Learner used: Two-class logistic regression
trans-unit.target: Learner used: Two-class logistic regression

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tipped".
trans-unit.target: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tipped".

trans-unit.source: Our original down-sampled dataset has a few columns that are target leaks for this classification experiment.
trans-unit.target: Our original down-sampled dataset has a few columns that are target leaks for this classification experiment.

trans-unit.source: In particular : tip\class, tip\amount, and total\_amount reveal information about the target label that is not available at testing time.
trans-unit.target: In particular : tip\class, tip\amount, and total\_amount reveal information about the target label that is not available at testing time.

trans-unit.source: We remove these columns from consideration using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: We remove these columns from consideration using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The snapshot below shows our experiment to predict whether or not a tip was paid for a given trip.
trans-unit.target: The snapshot below shows our experiment to predict whether or not a tip was paid for a given trip.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: For this experiment, our target label distributions were roughly 1:1.
trans-unit.target: For this experiment, our target label distributions were roughly 1:1.

trans-unit.source: The snapshot below shows the distribution of tip class labels for the binary classification problem.
trans-unit.target: The snapshot below shows the distribution of tip class labels for the binary classification problem.

trans-unit.source: As a result, we obtain an AUC of 0.987 as shown in the figure below.
trans-unit.target: As a result, we obtain an AUC of 0.987 as shown in the figure below.

trans-unit.source: Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip amounts paid for the trip, using the previously defined classes.
trans-unit.target: Multiclass classification**: To predict the range of tip amounts paid for the trip, using the previously defined classes.

trans-unit.source: Learner used: Multiclass logistic regression
trans-unit.target: Learner used: Multiclass logistic regression

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tip\_class" which can take one of five values (0,1,2,3,4).
trans-unit.target: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tip\_class" which can take one of five values (0,1,2,3,4).

trans-unit.source: As in the binary classification case, we have a few columns that are target leaks for this experiment.
trans-unit.target: As in the binary classification case, we have a few columns that are target leaks for this experiment.

trans-unit.source: In particular : tipped, tip\amount, total\amount reveal information about the target label that is not available at testing time.
trans-unit.target: In particular : tipped, tip\amount, total\amount reveal information about the target label that is not available at testing time.

trans-unit.source: We remove these columns using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: We remove these columns using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The snapshot below shows our experiment to predict in which bin a tip is likely to fall ( Class 0: tip = $0, class 1 : tip > $0 and tip <= $5, Class 2 : tip > $5 and tip <= $10, Class 3 : tip > $10 and tip <= $20, Class 4 : tip > $20)
trans-unit.target: The snapshot below shows our experiment to predict in which bin a tip is likely to fall ( Class 0: tip = $0, class 1 : tip > $0 and tip <= $5, Class 2 : tip > $5 and tip <= $10, Class 3 : tip > $10 and tip <= $20, Class 4 : tip > $20)

trans-unit.source: We now show what our actual test class distribution looks like.
trans-unit.target: We now show what our actual test class distribution looks like.

trans-unit.source: We see that while Class 0 and Class 1 are prevalent, the other classes are rare.
trans-unit.target: We see that while Class 0 and Class 1 are prevalent, the other classes are rare.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: For this experiment, we use a confusion matrix to look at our prediction accuracies.
trans-unit.target: For this experiment, we use a confusion matrix to look at our prediction accuracies.

trans-unit.source: This is shown below.
trans-unit.target: This is shown below.

trans-unit.source: Note that while our class accuracies on the prevalent classes is quite good, the model does not do a good job of "learning" on the rarer classes.
trans-unit.target: Note that while our class accuracies on the prevalent classes is quite good, the model does not do a good job of "learning" on the rarer classes.

trans-unit.source: Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.
trans-unit.target: Regression task**: To predict the amount of tip paid for a trip.

trans-unit.source: Learner used: Boosted decision tree
trans-unit.target: Learner used: Boosted decision tree

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tip\_amount".
trans-unit.target: For this problem, our target (or class) label is "tip\_amount".

trans-unit.source: Our target leaks in this case are : tipped, tip\class, total\amount ; all these variables reveal information about the tip amount that is typically unavailable at testing time.
trans-unit.target: Our target leaks in this case are : tipped, tip\class, total\amount ; all these variables reveal information about the tip amount that is typically unavailable at testing time.

trans-unit.source: We remove these columns using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.
trans-unit.target: We remove these columns using the <linkText>Project Columns[project-columns]</linkText><title></title> module.

trans-unit.source: The snapshot belows shows our experiment to predict the amount of the given tip.
trans-unit.target: The snapshot belows shows our experiment to predict the amount of the given tip.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: For regression problems, we measure the accuracies of our prediction by looking at the squared error in the predictions, the coefficient of determination, and the like.
trans-unit.target: For regression problems, we measure the accuracies of our prediction by looking at the squared error in the predictions, the coefficient of determination, and the like.

trans-unit.source: We show these below.
trans-unit.target: We show these below.

trans-unit.source: We see that about the coefficient of determination is 0.709, implying about 71% of the variance is explained by our model coefficients.
trans-unit.target: We see that about the coefficient of determination is 0.709, implying about 71% of the variance is explained by our model coefficients.

trans-unit.source: Important note: To learn more about Azure Machine Learning and how to access and use it, please refer to What's Machine Learning?.
trans-unit.target: Important note: To learn more about Azure Machine Learning and how to access and use it, please refer to What's Machine Learning?.

trans-unit.source: A very useful resource for playing with a bunch of Machine Learning experiments on Azure Machine Learning is the <linkText>gallery</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: A very useful resource for playing with a bunch of Machine Learning experiments on Azure Machine Learning is the <linkText>gallery</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The gallery covers a gamut of experiments and provides a thorough introduction into the range of capabilities of Azure Machine Learning.
trans-unit.target: The gallery covers a gamut of experiments and provides a thorough introduction into the range of capabilities of Azure Machine Learning.
